Comment: They‚Äôre both quite different scenarios.   At large, they‚Äôre both tricky because they have their own internal dynamics on whether or not they should or want to be states and their perception in the US.   On perception, there‚Äôs often a perception that both would be Democratic safe states if granted statehood - granting additional electoral college votes and Congressional representation to Democrats. While DC likely would be based on current voting trends there - Puerto Rico is less clear. They use technically a different system of parties but in fact, the majority of statewide posts are with those who affiliate more with the Republican alliance than the Democrats. Either way, I think pro-statehood people would argue this shouldn‚Äôt be a political game - if they‚Äôre citizens have to be states, they deserve to be represented equally (and many would make the argument that they are more deserving of, for example, their respective senators than smaller current states ((that are predominantly Republican)).   There‚Äôs a long-standing understanding that DC was intentionally created as it is to explicitly not be a state. This was, of course, before it was a thriving metropolis with a large number of long-term residents itself. That‚Äôs why, even in proposals to grant DC statehood, there is still a carve out (of various sizes) on what counts as the federal district still. Some have also proposed that it be subsumed outside of these carve outs into existing states (notably, part of the original territory made for DC has already be reabsorbed into Virginia). All to say, there‚Äôs no clear path forward on which way DC is granted statehood if it‚Äôs granted statehood at all. But notably, DC residents have expressed pretty strong support towards statehood.   Puerto Rico is less clear. There have been several referenda - each with their own flaws. There‚Äôs a general perception in the US, especially given the dynamic above about ‚Äòupsetting the balance‚Äô that unless Puerto Rico chooses statehood - it‚Äôs not for the US to force it. Again, this has gone to vote in different ways in Puerto Rico and almost all of them have had some issues - confusing questions, multi-step questions that don‚Äôt grant a strong majority or even plurality, boycotts on the vote, etc etc etc etc.

Comment: DC would not still exist. Article I of the Constitution states that the District cannot exceed ‚Äúten Miles square‚Äù. This language means ‚Äúa square with a side of 10 miles‚Äù, or 100 square miles‚Äînot 10 square miles.  100 square miles is exactly what was donated by Maryland and Virginia as part of the Residence Act of 1790.   A portion of this District to the west of the Potomac River was returned in Virginia in 1846 resulting in the shape of the District we know today. All together, D.C. comprises 68.34 miles‚Äîwell below the 100 square mile limit set by the constitution.   It would take a constitutional amendment to change that.
